Theoretical information.

Basic information about Markdown

To create a title, use the ( # ) sign.

# This is heading 1
## This is heading 2
### This is heading 3
#### This is heading 4

To make the text bold, enclose it with double asterisks.:

This text is **bold**.

To set the text in italics, enclose it in single asterisks.:

This text is *italic*.

To make the text bold and italicized, enclose it in triple asterisks.:

This is text is both ***bold and italic***.

Quotation blocks are created using the symbol >:

> The drought had lasted now for ten million years, and the reign of
the terrible lizards had long since ended. Here on the Equator, in
the continent which would one day be known as Africa, the battle
for existence had reached a new climax of ferocity, and the victor
was not yet in sight. In this barren and desiccated land, only the
small or the swift or the fierce could flourish, or even hope to
survive.

An unordered (bulleted) list can be formatted using asterisks or dashes.:

- List item 1
- List item 2
- List item 3

To nest one list into another, add an indentation for the elements of the child list.:

- List item 1
 - List item A
 - List item B
- List item 2

The ordered list can be formatted using the appropriate numbers.:

1. First instruction
1. Second instruction
1. Third instruction

To nest one list into another, add an indentation for the elements of the child list.:

1. First instruction
 1. Sub-instruction
 1. Sub-instruction
1. Second instruction

The Markdown syntax for an embedded link consists of the [link text] part, representing- containing the hyperlink text, and parts of (file-name.md ) is the URL or name of the file to which the link is given.:

[link text](file-name.md)

Markdown supports both embedding code fragments into a sentence and placing them between sentences as separate fenced blocks. Fenced code blocks are an easy way to highlight syntax for code snippets. The general format of the protected code blocks:

In-text formulas are made similarly to LaTeX formulas. For example, the formula sin2(ð‘¥) + cos2(ð‘¥) = 1 is written as:

$\sin^2 (x) + \cos^2 (x) = 1$

Processing files in Markdown format

We will use Pandoc to process files in Markdown format. https://pandoc.org/. Specifically, we will need the pandoc program, pandoc-citeproc. https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/releases , pandoc-crossref https://github.com/lierdakil/pandoc-crossref/releases.

Convert the file README.md it can be done as follows:

pandoc README.md -o README.pdf

Or so

pandoc README.md -o README.docx
